metadata.sermon_start_end: There is a touch of greatness in every person. In some it is out in the open in all they do, in the way they walk and talk and bear themselves. This strange attractiveness, this winsome greatness is what we have come to hear so much about as charisma. [...] But they that wait upon the Lord shall renew their strength; they shall mount up with wing as eagles; they shall run and not be weary; and they shall walk, and not faint (Isaiah 40:29-31).

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon uses 1 Samuel 15 as a narrative backdrop, but it fails to identify what is unique to this text. Instead of extracting a word that can be found 'nowhere else', the preacher uses Saul as a general archetype for human 'greatness' and 'failure'. The specific theological weight of the rejection of the first king of Israel is subsumed under general psychological observations.
quotes: Saul, Israel's first king, might well instruct us this morning, in the bright uplands and the low valleys, the high qualities and the base failures which make up the lives of most of us.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Identify the specific theological scandal of 1 Samuel 15: why does God demand total destruction (herem), and why is Saul's 'mercy' actually a form of rebellion? Avoid making Saul a mirror for 'the lives of most of us'.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is no evidence of Greek or Hebrew study, nor a deep engagement with the religious history of Israel. The preacher treats the text as a moral fable. The concept of 'herem' (the ban) is mentioned but dismissed as something that could have been a 'forward moral step' if Saul had acted out of mercy, which ignores the theocratic context of the passage.
quotes: Samuel believed that the command of God was that the Amalekites and all their possessions... were to be wiped out.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Engage with the historical-theological necessity of the command in the context of Israel's covenant, rather than projecting modern 'mercy and humanity' onto the text.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete in its use of anecdotes (Kent State, the preacher O'Mitchell), but these anecdotes often distract from the text rather than applying it. The application remains largely in the realm of personal reputation and 'not being shamed', which is a psychological application rather than a theological one.
quotes: Don't let the children see how short I am of what I ought to be.
Lord, rebuke me but make me not a public disgrace.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Shift application from the fear of 'public disgrace' to the theological reality of being 'rejected by God' as it pertains to the contemporary hearer's vocation.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a 'sandwich' structure: general introduction, a bit of Saul, then a personal anecdote, then more Saul, then another anecdote. The hearer is not drawn into the text; rather, the text is pulled into the preacher's thematic framework of 'greatness'.
quotes: Now Saul is kin to all of us.
Did I ever tell you about a preacher in my earliest years whose name was O'Mitchell?
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Allow the text's own structure to dictate the movement of the sermon, so that the application arises directly from the exposition of the Word.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: Misery is present but framed as 'failure' or 'shame' rather than ontological misery before God. Redemption is hinted at through 'repentance', but it leans heavily on human effort to 'repair the broken altar'. The Trinitarian background is weak.
quotes: Now there is nothing to do but to set about by your own repentance and confession and promise to repair the broken altar.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Emphasize that redemption is an act of God (extra nos) rather than a human 'promise to repair'.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon acknowledges the reality of being 'rejected' and the 'saddest words' of sin. It takes the possibility of loss seriously, particularly 'temporal loss' (loss of career, reputation, and calling).
quotes: ...the days of glory snatched from him because the Lord had rejected him.
We might all pray that we might stop short of that place where the Lord will bring us down for all to see.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Connect the 'temporal loss' of reputation more clearly to the 'eternal loss' of standing before God, avoiding a purely social definition of 'shame'.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned, but he is not the telos. He appears as a name in a hymn or a general reference to 'lives in Jesus Christ', but the sermon's actual goal is human 'worship' and 'waiting on the Lord' to find strength. Grace is secondary to the human 'touch of greatness'.
quotes: All was lost, but his power to call on God was not lost.
Now what is wrong in many of our lives is that we do not take time to worship God.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Make Christ the necessary solution to Saul's (and our) rejection, rather than suggesting that man's 'power to call on God' remains an intact 'touch of greatness'.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1350 words, the sermon likely lasts 13-14 minutes. This fails Dekker's requirement of 20 minutes for 'depth'. The brevity results in a reliance on anecdotes rather than sustained theological 'breadth'.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Extend the exposition of the text and the dogmatic implications of God's rejection to reach the necessary 20-minute threshold for depth.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's criteria primarily by substituting psychological 'greatness' and 'shame' for the theological categories of election and rejection. It is too short to achieve the required depth and relies heavily on anecdotal evidence rather than rigorous exegesis. The Christological focus is nominal rather than structural.
strengths: The sermon is concrete and avoids 'general truths' by using vivid, albeit non-biblical, illustrations.
It maintains a sense of the 'seriousness of life' and the possibility of being lost or rejected.
weaknesses: Insufficient length (approx. 14 minutes) prevents theological depth.
The 'touch of greatness' theme borders on an anthropological optimism that contradicts the radical nature of Saul's rejection.
Exegesis is replaced by moralizing narrative.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is not a sermon in the sense of Dekker's definition. It is a moral-psychological speech that uses a biblical character as an illustrative tool rather than an actualization of the Word of God.
